headline: Easy Swedish Apple Pie
description: This lovely Swedish apple pie covered with a sweet, cinnamon crust is perfectly tart and tasty. It's easy to make too, no need to roll out dough.
name: Easy Swedish Apple Pie
recipeIngredient: 1.5 pounds Granny Smith apples - peeled, cored and sliced

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
Toss apples with 1 tablespoon sugar and pour them into a pie plate.
Thoroughly mix together 1 cup sugar with flour, butter, egg, and cinnamon. Spread this evenly over the top of the pie.
Bake in the preheated oven until apples have cooked and topping is golden brown, 40 to 45 minutes.

review.reviewBody: When I want an easy, delicious fruit-based recipe, this is my go-to. I always have apples on hand that need to be used and I'll also add anything else starting to ripen too much: berries, plums, pears. Along with almond extract, nutmeg, ginger and slivered almonds. I really like the cookie-ish crust. I cut the amount of butter some to save my arteries. But the more butter, of course, the more delicious.
Easy and delicious!
added lemonjuice to the bare apple pieces and halved the sugar. The flour mix is cakey and was difficult to spread evenly.
This pie is delicious!! I used 1/2 cup regular flour and 1/2 cup almond flour and only used 3/4cup sugar. Crust baked to a golden brown. Served with a small scoop of ice cream.
Great recipe added more sugar and cinnamons was a hit in my home.
This is like a giant cookie with apples. I followed the instructions carefully. This does not seem like a pie. It was good, but really a cookie. Not sure if i missed something

This is really easy to make and delicious. I didn’t change the recipe at all. I used a 9 inch springform pan because I saw it in one of the pictures uploaded here. That worked just fine. I lined the bottom of the pan with parchment. I also made vanilla ice cream for the occasion.

I never knew baking an apple pie could be so easy & it taste great. No need to make a dough crust and roll out. Simply add a few ingredients together and spread over the top of the apples & there is your crust-so tasty. Only apple pie I have made now for 2 years.

I use my apple/peeler/corer/slicer gadget to create ¼ inch thick slices, which I cut into quarters (bite size). Pile fruit into a buttered deep dish pie pan, then toss apples with 4 Tbsp (¼ cup) each lemon juice and granulated sugar, then proceed with the rest of the recipe.
I thought it was good and easy to make. Green apples taste the best in it.
I made this with brown sugar and cut the butter to half a cup. If you like nuts, you GOTTA try this with walnuts! Yum!!!
Still in the oven and I added cinnamon to apple mixture.

I have made this multiple times and it's perfect as is. It tastes a lot like an apple cake my mom used to make.
After making it several times, I have added a sprinkle of cinnamon and nutmeg to 1 TBP of sugars on the apples, but just a suggestion to enhance the apples a bit. Again, it's perfect as written. Always gone quickly in our house!
easy, delicious, I used more cinnamon 2 teaspoons, 1/2 teaspoon of nutmeg, grated and chopped walnuts.
Best pie ever and so easy to make!
This had to be 1 of the easiest pies ever. I made it as recipe called for. I think I’d add a bit more sugar and cinnamon to apples next time.

Wow ! This is very delicious! (At first, I was wondering if it didn't look very good at first glance.) I thought I would use whipped cream for toppings like someone else did, but I thought I didn't need it. As a result, I was able to make a very delicious dessert. Thank you.
Loved it just as is. Going to try it with pears and apples next. Very easy and very delicious, makes it a winner!
Wonderful, yummy and very easy to make!

This turned out great with some changes. It would not have been as tasty without the additions below. Added cinnamon and a small amount of nutmeg to the apples as well as the topping. Used half white and half brown sugar. Also I hate pies where the apples are still firm so I baked my apples for about 15 minutes before adding the topping and then baked as directed. The apples were nice and tender but not mushy. If you like your apples a little firm then don’t bake them first. This was a nice easy recipe and I would make again.
So easy to make with every day ingredients.

It's a great recipe. I made some changes and adjusted it to my diabetic diet. I used whole wheat pastry flour and splenda sugar blend. For the apples I added a tsp. of cinnamon, a tbl. of vanilla, and 1/2 tsp. of nutmeg and baked as directed. It was delicious!
M. Clark
I have made this for years...my recipe calls for raisins mixed with the apples and crushed walnuts in the crust!

Awesome. The kind of pie you have to go back for a second helping. I used Both brown and white sugar . Plus I threw a few blueberries in for color, you may see in my picture. This is an easy keeper recipe. And BTW I made it gluten free by using rice flour, no one would be able to tell the difference.
wife said it was the best apple pie she had had
I cut the sugar by 1/3. Added spices to the apples. Used half flour and half oatmeal.
I've made this twice. First time I tried the exact recipe. Second time I added cinnamon to the apples and also caramel morsels over apples but under crust. It went fast!
So easy and so good. Followed the recipe exactly, and it was a perfect apple “cookie cake” (as my son calls it). The apples almost melt away into the pie/cake part.

Made as is pretty much with 2 key changes: I love buckwheat flour, so I used it. (It is NOT a pretty dessert made this way!) 
 Also had just baked boozy cranberries with bourbon similar to recipes here, but half the sugar. I added a cup of those to the pie. Dash of salt. The rest was pretty much the same. Very easy. Thank you!

I didn't have any nuts on hand so I added about half a cup of homemade granola, very good. I have also used fresh plums in lieu of apples (plum season huge this year) and 3 tbsp of sugar rather than 1 tbsp as in the recipe. Also very good!! This is a great recipe!!

Suggested changes make this a 5 star! TO THE DRAINED APPLES: add 1 T. brown sugar along with the 1 T. white sugar + 1 tsp. cinnamon or apple pie spice. BATTER: Use another 1 tsp. cinnamon or apple pie spice. Use half white & half brown sugar. Butter should be soft, not melted. Hint: Distribute clumps of batter on apple layer & spread as best you can as it's very sticky! Batter will spread just fine as it cooks. It's delicious & easy!
I made it but I added chopped walnuts. Was so good

I have been using this recipe since the mid '80s. A bit less sugar, some nutmeg added to apples and half butter/half oleo are my changes. The baking time can be longer if using oleo. Absolutely the best 'cakey pie' ever! (just made it and can hardly wait for it to cool.)

I have made this twice with years in between the making. Both times it has run over, covering the bottom of my oven with melted butter and filling the room with smoke. I forgot about that happening when I just made it this second time. You must all be using a DEEP dish 9" pie plate? I do like the pie in the end. I just need to remember to use the bigger pie plate.

Best apple pie ever. I have been making this since the 70s. I add chopped walnuts to the spread. The best part is that it makes it's own crust. Great served warm and so easy to make. Everyone loves it.
Easy to make and great taste, my neighbors love it.

It was a hit at Thanksgiving. I may use a mixture of apples next time as using all granny smiths was a bit tart for my personal taste. ( The topping was very sweet so it balanced out if you do use all granny smith.) I did add 1 TB of brown sugar and some spices to my apples before putting them in the pan, as other reviewers suggested. I used softened butter and not melted butter. The topping baked into a beautiful cohesive top. Would make again.

I can't even count how many times I've made this pie at this point! Everyone always loves it and asks me to bring it again next time. (My cousin asked for THREE for Christmas this year!) I love it because the easiness to impressiveness ratio is spot on! Delicious as-is, but I often will add some nutmeg and allspice, or in a hurry a few shakes of Penzey's pie spice, just to spruce it up a little bit. But you can't go wrong with apple, cinnamon, and sugar! And the crush is kind of like a big cookie... Mmm!

I made this as written, but added some cinnamon and maple extract to the apples. I also had more apples that I needed to use. Delicious!! I followed the others who suggested softened (not melted) butter. Next time I will probably use less sugar, it is fairly sweet. I would call this a terrific Apple cobbler.
This was easy. Wasn't quite sweet enough, could have been the apples. The crust/topping is good. Will make this again.

This was very good. I did make a few changes of course. Firstly, I used whatever apples I had on hand, not Granny Smith. Secondly, I did use a bottom pastry crust but only because I had one in the freezer. After slicing the apples (I DID NOT PEEL THEM) I tossed them with a bit of brown sugar and generous sprinkle of cinnamon. Then made the batter, using Brown Sugar only and slightly less melted butter. It tasted amazing and the top "crust" was beautiful brown and crunchy.
Absolutely my go to pie - my family calls it pake - half pie half cake. Similar to others I toss some cinnamon in the apples and add a dash of vanilla to the 'crust.

A favorite have been making it for years but lost the recipe, my only addition to this recipe would be to add 1/2 cup of chopped walnuts. That was in the version I lost and highly recommend the addition.

this recipe is a huge hit! I've been using this recipe for years and it's never failed. You can get creative with it as well, I had some leftover dried cranberries and decided to throw them in with the apples and it was AMAZING ! Another time, I added raisins and cranberries, again...AMAZING! Absolutely a favorite...super easy...never fail!

I love this recipe! It is so easy. I have made it over and over. There is only one substitute that I make! I use Braeburn and Golden Delicious Apples. Otherwise the recipe is made as is stated. The only thing that I had reservations about was the topping. The first time I made the pie, I didn't know how to put the topping on the apples. It is easiest to take spoonful's of the topping and place it on top of the fruit. Then I use a pastry knife to spread it evenly (as possible) over the apples. It will form the "crust" as it cooks. The slice holds it's shape, even though there is not a bottom crust to hold the slice together! Delicious! Not to sweet, but not tart either!

This was an okay apple pie.

I listened to other reviewers and added in spice with the apples themselves and a mix of them to the "crust".

I also added in a tablespoon each of cornflour and chia seeds to the apples as normally there is a lot of juice floating round in this type of recipe. But maybe it is not needed as that layer turned out with very little sauce, maybe the pie crust is meant to soak it up?

No changes. Making another one now.
It's a hit in my house.
This pie is just wonderful the best ever I will definitely make it again

not hard.
quite easy

I made this for thanksgiving. Used 5 yellow apples with 1 TBS cornstarch . My husband was unsure how people would like a crust less apple pie but everyone loved loved it and out of the 5 pies and cakes this was the only one finished - to the last crumb. I heated it up and served with ice cream . Next time I'll use Granny Smiths , I bet it will be even better. Best way to describe it is oowy goowy goodness!!!

Oct. 8, 2015. It's apple time again. This is one of the easiest and very good pies to make. I've made it several times now and it comes out great every time. You can even make it with store bought crust, but my own is better. This house eats a lot of apple pies in the fall and this is one of the best.

I have made this multiple times now, family requests, and will continue to make. Easy and reminds me of apple dumplings but not as much work. I do add cloves & nutmeg and sometimes add raisens or craisens . It makes a little sauce if you add a few spoonsfull of water or apple cider over the apples before adding the topping. This is a keeper. Great served with vanilla ice cream or warm with milk poured over it. YUM YUM
Try a different recipe ,I had one in my all recipe box saved now I can't find my box

Excellent, will definitely make again.
Added a pinch of cinnamon, nutmeg and ginger to the apples which gave the apples great flavour.

This is not a traditional pie, more like an apple cobbler. It's so easy to make and tasted much better than I expected. I used only one Granny Smith apple and the rest were a red apple variety so I could have cut back on the sugar. I baked it for 45 minutes and the filling was still juicy and the crust was still soft. It did run over the pie plate into the oven so next time I will put something under it. The taste of the original recipe was fine for me but I might try the changes suggested the next time I make it and I will definitely make this again!
Yum!!! This is so easy to make and one of the best Apple pies I've had. It reminds me of snicker doodle cookies, but with Apple!

Excellent recipe! This recipe also works really well with Asian Pears. We have Apple and Asian Pear trees and this recipe has become a family favorite. It is nice to be able to bake an apple pie without having to roll a crust. Special thanks to Northlake-Kat for her recipe improvements; I also added 1 t. Almond Extract to the crust ingredients. Thank you!!

Not my favorite. I substituted 2 Splenda packets for the sugar in the topping, which turned out okay but the pie itself is dry. Will likely go back to the old fashioned double crust country apple pie.
Amazing fail safe recipe- I added extra cinnamon but then we love it!! So easy and definite crowd pleaser- only problem we always want more when the dish is empty!!!
LOVE this

I made this a year ago, and it was perfect!
Made it a month later and the topping ran off.
Made it this morning and topping is all over the baking sheet I put down just in case. What might I have done wrong the latter two times?
Worked fine, I chopped all my apples up small and sifted them with sugar and cinnamon. Just make sure the top spreads, edge to edge. I will not be making it again.

I absolutely love this "pie!" I made it with corn flour instead of all-purpose, and it still tasted amazing! I think the corn flavor actually accented the apples. I'm making it with cake flour right now and hopefully it will turn out as good. I'm going to be making this all the time! 
My husband hates traditional pie because of the crust, and he actually had two pieces when I made this! It's such an easy recipe that I am excited to alter it and see what different combinations will work out. Thank you so much for this recipe!

This Is my first time I have stopped to rate a recipe. I have been told I make the best apple pie that they have tasted. But this recipe is equal to my best apple pie if not better. I did follow the recipe 99% as the recipe called for. The only thing I did as other Reviewers suggested was I added an extra quarter teaspoon of cinnamon to the 1 teaspoon, 2 teaspoons would of taken away of the apples it would of been too much of a cinnamon taste instead of complementing the apples. I also just soften the butter instead of melting it and I added a good half a cup of chopped pecans to it to give it an extra texture. So instead of pouring the topping on I was able to Pat and cover all the apples dealing in the juices. The pie came out perfect. To cut some calories without any sacrifice of taste, I used 1/2 cup of white sugar and 1/2 cup of Splenda brown sugar then a good pinch of regular dark brown sugar as I used 7 Granny Smith apples. I have an automatic apple peeler, corer n slicer . I make so many apple desserts and applesauce , it is a must in my kitchen. Judi Hill Port Charlotte FL
So yum!

I thought this was fantastic. More like apple dumplings maybe, but still excellent. I've made it several times, I do put a bit of cinnamon in the apples in addition to the crust, but I'm silly about cinnamon. I am disabled and don't have the stamina for a conventional apple pie, but I could handle this just fine.Thanks for posting this recipe!!

Oh yes, I tried this recipe and BOY am I glad! Took some ideas and added almond extract to the batter with a little spice (cinnamon and nutmeg). This tastes like a wonderful apple pie without making a traditional crust with all it's the mess! I used the bowl I mixed the apple slices in to also beat up the batter (after pouring apple slices into the greased pie dish),easier clean-up! The crust was a little thick, so dollop it on then spread, but the heat evens it all out. It comes out sweet and slightly crunchy YUM! It is definitely a sweet dessert, but my tart apples needed that!

I've made this pie numerous times with great results each time. Everyone loves the fact that there's no crust to add those extra calories. The only thing I'm careful about is using my stoneware to bake this in. It allows the extra moisture from the apples to absorb into the stone - giving you a perfect pie!
Tasty. Fewer ingredients make an easier recipe

I had a few small Granny Smiths leftover from a small bag that I had purchased. Didn't want to toss them out, had never made an apple pie before....don't care much for it. OMG!!!! this has to be the most simple recipe for anything I've ever made. It turned out absolutely wonderful...my apples were very tart, so depending on the taste of future pies I might suggest that more sugar be added to the apples themselves. 
 My biggest surprise was that after the pie cooled when cut it hung together very well while removing it from the glass pie dish.

 AWESOME RECIPE!!!!!

Loved this pie! Simple ingredients and amazing crust over top of the pie that is not soggy but really quite hearty and crunchy ish. By far the best apple pie I've had. We did add some cinnamon sugar sprinkled on the top before baking which was a great addition.

this pie is much better, when it's cold. :D
I added some cinnamon into the apples and it turned out quite well. but still, I have to say that this wasn't the best pie I've ever eaten. it wasn't bad, just... the taste wasn't perfect... I don't know how to say it. :D it misses something...

Delicious! I incorporated reviewers' advice and made the following changes:
- Added cinnamon, nutmeg, and cloves to the apples
- In the crust, replaced half the regular sugar with brown, and added a splash of almond extract. I also used oil instead of butter and it was fine. 
Thanks for a winner.

So easy and fabulous taste! I used 3/4 stick margarine and added cinammon to apples!!!!! Crust nice and crunchy with less butter/margarine. I also cut apples in larger slices and they did real well!!!!! This is a keeper!

Really enjoyed this "pie." I had to bake it 15 minutes longer than the recipe called because the center was still quite doughy. However, it tasted great, had a nice crunchy cookie-like top. The only comment I have to the recipe was that I thought the apples could have been a bit sweeter. Next time (and there will be a next time) I will either add a bit more sugar or include other sweeter apples in with the tart apples.
Sooo yummy! Made 3 pies for guests and this was the only one that there was nothing left of! Making 2 for Thanksgiving!!! Awesome also sprinkled cinnamon on top vs. in the topping.

I loved this Apple pie as well as everyone in the house. I liked it because I didn't have to make a crust and it tasted wonderful. Everyone else loved the crunchy deliriousness. Easy to make, I just finished making one for Thanksgiving Dinner tomorrow. Only thing I changed the first time was I used less apples so it would fit in my pie plates.
Very easy and amazing in taste. It was just a little sweet for me but everyone else loved it!
I only reduced the sugar to 3/4 of a cup, but left the rest the same. Worked beautifully! Deliciously tart.

This is much easier and way more delicious than any pastry apple pie. The crust is crunchy and soft at the same time, with the perfect sweetness to complement the tart apples. The first time I made it the apples practically disintegrated, so I cut them a little thicker the second time. I also spread the topping so that it didn't go all the way to edge. This kept it from getting too thin, hard and brown right at the edge. My search for the perfect apple dessert is over.
I loved this recipe! It turned out fantastically! But WARNING!! Use real butter and Not Margarine. Margarine makes the top soggy. That I didn't love.
Do not put in a crust...I did, it was still good but nest time I will not use a crust as the filling is a crust!
Delicious. Easy.

Best apple pie! I've made this for years and it continues to be one of my favorites. Absolutely delicious and easy! Instead of straight white sugar, I use 1 part brown sugar and 2 parts sugar for topping--gives it more richness, flavor, moister and density. Excellent either way though!

Amazing. I wanted to make an apple pie but didn't feel like dealing with the dough and rolling it out and everything. This pie was just as delicious if not more so than a regular apple pie. I ran out of flour while I was mixing the batter, and all I had was some apple cinnamon muffin mix. I ended up using about 1/2 cup of the muffin mix and 1/2 cup flour, but it actually turned out very well. Highly recommend this recipe.

My family loved this recipe so much I had to make two! I followed what other reviewers said and added 1 tablespoon of white sugar, 1 tablespoon of brown sugar, and 1 tablespoon of cinnamon. Even my sister who doesn't like apple pie was telling me over and over how she loved the crust. Will definitely use again.

This is so good! I'll not mess with making crust for apple pie ever again. I did use the Grany Smiths and added a T each of brown and white sugar, cinnamon and nutmeg to the apples. I like it sweet. I didn't use the spices in the crust. I threw in a handful of Crasins too. I think this is much better than cobbler with the crunchy and flavorful "crust". Thanks to the contributor.
Wonderful and easy! Like apple pie with a chewy/crunchy sugar cookie crust!
Just like Grammie's!
Sooooo Good and soooooo easy. Definitely keeping this one. Who needs all that extra pie crust. This is perfect.
AWESOME!! it takes no time at all and my whole family loved it. They even liked it more than a traditional apple pie! :)
My family loved it at Thanksgiving. Made it gluten free, and was a little concerned by how it looked, but that is not the recipe's fault. Seems like a pretty solid variation to apple pie.
Kind of weird texture, but quite yummy. Flavor is wonderful. I am a big apple pie a la mode person, but I actually prefer this without ice cream. Already had two pieces. :-)

VERY GOOD! Big hit at Thanksgiving this year! I followed the advice of some of the reviewers and changed 2 of the instructions/ingredients as follow: for the filling I mixed 1T of brown sugar, 1t cinnamon and a bit of fresh nutmeg together with the 1T granulated sugar and then tossed it all with the apples. For the crust, I used softened instead of melted butter and I substitued one-half cup light brown sugar for one-half cup of the the granulated sugar. Baking time was about perfect at 45 min.
I am normally not a fan of apple pies, but this was amazingly good! It's a keeper, and I'll definitely make it again.

I've been searching for a swedish apple pie recipe to teach my kid to bake. This is almost exactly like the one I learned when I was little. Easy for kiddos to do pretty much by themselves, and absolutely delicious! I used a bit less cinnamon than called for, and my hubby (who doesn't do desserts) was begging for it to be a regular menu item. :)
Not bad, but just like somebody else said: this is apples with a giant cookie on top. I reduced the sugar in half and it still was pretty sweet. Although, I didn't use granny smiths.
It tastes better when cold. It must be refrigerated because of the egg though so be careful. Wasn't as good as my apple crumble so I don't think I'll make it again.

This pie is a great way to avoid all the hassle associated with pie crust. If you prefer a crunchy crust you cook it a little longer but be careful not to overcook it because then you'll end up with a crust that is too hard and you can't blame it on the recipe if that happens. I added 1/2 tsp more of cinnamon and decided to include 1/2 tsp each of cloves and nutmeg to spice it up a bit. The results were delicious. This pie is so easy to make that it's practically fool proof. Try it and I think you'll be pleasantly surprised that something so tasty can also be so easy.
